docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: We are surprised that your editorial "Can You Trust the A.A.R.P.?" (May 20) questioned the credibility of the American Association of Retired Persons.

docs.lead_paragraph: Assembly Democrats in New York's State Legislature have outlined an inventive way for the state to deregulate hospital rates without harming hospitals that treat the poor and train medical residents. Speaker Sheldon Silver's proposal may not be the last word on state health reform -- it lacks details, omits some attractive features found in Gov. George Pataki's health-care reform and could be challenged in court. Yet the crux of his plan finds a way around a Federal law that has stymied previous deregulatory efforts. Under current law, Albany sets hospital rates for patients who are not enrolled in health maintenance organizations. Those rates are high enough to cover the costs of treating uninsured patients and training residents. The law expires at the end of June and is unraveling anyway because patients are increasingly turning to H.M.O.'s.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey's fiercely competitive health insurance market will soon become even rougher. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey yesterday agreed to merge with Anthem Inc., a big, diversified Midwestern insurer. The merger will create the nation's second-biggest holder of Blue Cross and Blue Shield franchises. The deal will help give New Jersey Blue Cross, which already covers 1.9 million residents, the financial heft to slug it out in the managed-care market with the likes of U.S. Healthcare, Prudential and Oxford Health Plans.

headline.main: Health Plans In New Jersey Face Rivalries

headline.main: In Defense of the Defense of Marriage Act

docs.lead_paragraph: Bob Dole says he wants to pass health-care reform before he steps down as majority leader and leaves the Senate next month. The task will not be easy. Bills passed by the House and Senate would perform a valuable service by requiring insurers to offer coverage to workers who lose or quit their jobs, a requirement known as portability, though nothing in these modest bills guarantees that coverage would be affordable for individual workers. But Congress is hung up over three ideology-laden provisions added to one bill or the other. Mr. Dole has yet to resolve the wrangling. The House bill would enshrine a favorite conservative remedy, the so-called medical savings accounts. The bill would provide a tax break for money deposited into these special accounts and the money would be used to pay routine medical bills. The owners of these accounts would cover their large medical bills by buying a high-deductible, or catastrophic, policy.

docs.lead_paragraph: L. Ben Lytle, whose Anthem Inc. is acquiring Blue Cross-Blue Shield of New Jersey, apparently figures there is one thing for certain in America's fast-changing health care system: you have to be big to be a player. Under the leadership of Mr. Lytle, a 49-year-old Texas native, the once-sleepy mutual insurance company has blossomed from its roots running the Blue Cross-Blue Shield business in Indiana into a $6 billion health care enterprise -- so diversified that competitors of one subsidiary can be customers or suppliers of another. Fortune magazine ranked the company as the nation's 217th-largest in revenues in 1995.

docs.lead_paragraph: With the spread of managed-care companies and their efforts to contain costs, many doctors say they are losing control over working conditions, treatments and incomes. In response, some are taking a most uncommon step to protect their interests. They are joining labor unions. With typically six-figure incomes, private-practice physicians would seem to have little in common with the toilers of office, field and factory. But as they lose their independence, 4,000 of the white-cloaked stalwarts of free enterprise have taken up the union banner.

headline.main: Feeling Devalued by Change, Doctors Seek Union Banner

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey Blue Cross Said to Join Big Insurer New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield has agreed to join forces with the Anthem Group, a big Midwestern company that owns Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky, people with knowledge of the deal said.

docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield, the largest health insurer in New Jersey, with 1.9 million enrollees, has agreed to join forces with a big Midwestern company that is one of the nation's largest health insurers, people with knowledge of the deal said last night. The deal would link the New Jersey insurer, which is struggling to finance the costly expansion into managed care, with a company whose publicly traded subsidiary can raise money through the stock market. That company, the Anthem Group, is based in Indianapolis and already owns Blue Cross plans in Indiana, Ohio and Kentucky.
